thread.title: Star Wars: out of this world ticket sales for The Force Awakens
thread.title_full: Star Wars: out of this world ticket sales for The Force Awakens

author: Garry Maddox
title: Star Wars: out of this world ticket sales for The Force Awakens
text:

Trailer - Star Wars: The Force Awakens (trailer 3) Coming to Australian cinemas December 17.
PT2M4S http://www.smh.com.au/action/externalEmbeddedPlayer?id=d-44tz7 620 349 October 20, 2015 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Star Wars trailer shakes the internet The Force Awakens: frame by frame Movie session times Full movies coverage Two months out from its opening in cinemas, the new Star Wars movie has sold more than $1 million in advanced tickets in the first four hours of release.
The rush from Australian fans saw some midnight sessions of The Force Awakens sell-out, with more screenings added to keep up with demand.
The new poster for Star Wars: The Force Awakens .
One leading chain, Event Cinemas, reported that 1200 tickets sold in the first minute when they went on sale at 8am on Tuesday.
Advertisement Within 10 minutes, the chain had sold 10,000 tickets. And in three hours, director J.J. Abrams' new instalment of the sci-fi saga had clocked up 30,000 tickets.
In Sydney, the most popular Event cinemas for Star Wars fans were George Street in the city, Bondi Junction, Miranda and Parramatta.
A spokesman for the chain said its previous best one-day advanced ticket sales were for The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn â€“ Part 2 , with 7,726, and Harry Potter and The Deathly Hollows Part 2 , with 7,258.
The first Star Wars movie in a decade quickly topped the chain's entire pre-sales for The Avengers , 26,988 tickets, before that ensemble superhero movie went on to take $53.2 million at the Australian box office.
Ahead of its opening on December 17, Disney has ramped up the hype for The Force Awakens by releasing a new trailer and poster as advanced tickets went on sale.
With two other big movies headed for cinemas next month - the James Bond movie Spectre on November 12 and The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part II on November 19 - it shapes as a booming end to the year for Australian cinemas.
While nothing is guaranteed until The Force Awakens screens - remember the hype before the two Matrix sequels opened in 2003? - the cinema industry will expect Star Wars to be one of the few films to break $50 million at the box office.
The optimists hope it has a shot at topping Avatar 's exceptional $115.6 million but that will require a strongly positive response to the movie - with no Jar Jar Binks style backlash from die-hard fans - and many repeat visits by fans over summer.
"We anticipated the ticket sales for Star Wars: The Force Awakens to break records," said David Seargeant, group managing director of Amalgamated Holdings Ltd, which operates Event, Greater Union and Birch, Carroll & Coyle cinemas. "However, the pace in which this film has achieved this is remarkable."
Disney acquired the Star Wars franchise when it bought Lucasfilm in 2012, announcing a new trilogy, three more standalone films and related expansions to its theme park business.
"Judging by the unprecedented ticket pre-sale numbers for Star Wars: The Force Awakens , it's clear that The Force is strong in Australia," said Catherine Powell, managing director of Disney in Australia and New Zealand.
"Whilst we expected significant interest from the many passionate Star Wars fans in this country, we are delighted with the overwhelming response from Australians who want to experience the next chapter of this epic story during opening weekend and beyond."
